sentence: Equities in the U.S. were mostly higher on Monday, with the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq Composite halting four-day losing streaks as optimism about more tax cuts helped overshadow a downbeat day for tech giant Apple ( AAPL ).

The Dow Jones Industrial Average was unable to join its peers in the win column with Apple's loss weighing after the company came into the sights of President Donald Trump's tweeting over the weekend and Travelers Cos. ( TRV ) weakened as Atlantic coast states prepared for a category four Hurricane Florence.
Markets were dented last week as Trump jolted sentiment with talk of tariffs on China and a better-than-expected jobs report raised worries about faster interest-rate increases.
But reports Monday that US House Republicans are poised to introduce another round of tax cuts this week helped turn equity sentiment to the upside.
Among the S&P's sectors, information technology rose 0.3% as semiconductors recovered some of their recent losses.
Advanced Micro Devices ( AMD ) led the way on the S&P, rising 9.2% as Susquehanna said the company is gaining share in three key markets.
Utilities rose 0.6% in the best performance among the S&P's groups, while telecoms, real estate and industrials were also among the gainers.
On the downside, health care retreated 0.3% and financials dipped 0.1% as insurers weakened ahead of the storm.

Nike ( NKE ) rose the most among the blue-chips on the Dow after Wedbush added $5 to its price target on the athletics retailer, setting it at $90 ahead of fiscal first-quarter results due in about two weeks.
Home Depot ( HD ) was also in the green, as was Lowe's (LOW) with Florence expected to hit land later in the week.
But the Dow faltered overall as UnitedHealth Group (UNH) and Boeing (BA) dropped.

Here's where the markets stood by the close:

(+) NLST (+165.96%) Gets favorable claim construction order in ITC investigation of SK Hynix

(+) ECYT (+6.49%) FDA accepts radiographic progression free survival as alternative primary endpoint of Vision trial in addition to overall survival

(+) FTEK (+6.03%) Won $15.8 million in new orders from US and Chinese customers

(-) ESND (-9.93%) Board says Staples offer is superior to Genuine Parts (GPC) unit deal

(-) BABA (-3.7%) Executive Chairman Jack Ma will hand over to CEO Daniel Zhang next year
